title.value: Inter-individual differences in cortical thickness and their genomic underpinnings in autism spectrum disorder
title.justification: This title accurately captures the key focus of the paper on exploring differences in cortical thickness in individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and linking these differences to genetic factors.
title.quote: Title: Inter-individual differences in cortical thickness and their genomic underpinnings in autism spectrum disorder

extractions.description: This paper investigates the differences in cortical thickness among individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and explores the genetic factors associated with these anatomical differences. Using a large and diverse sample from the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project, the study examines neurodevelopmental differences and their potential pathophysiological mechanisms across different ASD clinical subgroups. It identifies brain regions where anatomical deviations in ASD individuals correlate with higher polygenic scores for ASD and other psychiatric conditions, linking these deviations to enriched genes in specific brain regions.

type.justification: The paper presents empirical research using data from the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project, performing statistical analyses on MRI data to identify anatomical and genetic variations in individuals with autism spectrum disorder.
type.quote: Our study examined neurodevelopmental differences in cortical thickness (CT) and their genomic underpinnings in a large and clinically diverse sample of 360 individuals with ASD and 270 typically developing controls (aged 6-30 years) within the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP).

name.justification: The primary research focus is on the use of neuroimaging techniques, particularly MRI, to study cortical thickness in the context of autism spectrum disorder.
name.quote: Neuroimaging in autism spectrum disorder: brain structure and function across the lifespan.

name.justification: The paper emphasizes the genomic underpinnings of observed neuroanatomical differences, reflecting its significant focus on genetics alongside neuroimaging.
name.quote: To link CT variability to etiological mechanisms, we utilized the AHBA to identify genes with a spatial pattern of expression resembling our imaging maps.

name.justification: The study focuses on autism spectrum disorder, contributing to the understanding of its neurobiological diversity and potential genetic factors.
name.quote: Objective. Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is accompanied by highly individualized neuroanatomical deviations that potentially map onto distinct genotypes and clinical phenotypes.

name.justification: The dataset used in the study is explicitly mentioned as the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project data, which provides neuroimaging and genotypic information of participants.
name.quote: This study utilized data provided by the EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP), a multicenter transdisciplinary study on stratification biomarkers for ASD (www.eu-aims.eu).

referenced_paper_title.value: The EU-AIMS Longitudinal European Autism Project (LEAP): clinical characterisation
referenced_paper_title.justification: The LEAP project is referenced within the paper as the primary source of participant data.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A comprehensive description of the sample has been published elsewhere (9).

name.justification: FreeSurfer is used in the paper for cortical surface reconstruction from MRI data, a crucial part of the methodological approach.
name.quote: FreeSurfer v6.0.0 software (http://surfer.nmr.mgh.harvard.edu/) was used to derive models of the cortical surface for each T1-weighted image.

referenced_paper_title.value: Cortical Surface-Based Analysis II: Inflation, Flattening, and a Surface-Based Coordinate System
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper references the use of FreeSurfer and its methodological basis as outlined in the literature.
referenced_paper_title.quote: These well-validated and fully automated procedures have been described extensively elsewhere (24, 25).
